player_decision.reason: Button open-raise with an Ace (A2o) in 3-handed. Small min-raise to 20 applies pressure to the blinds, often steals the antes/blinds, keeps pot manageable against larger stacks and avoids giving the aggressive big stack a free opportunity. Not worth folding or shoving.

Ad Qh is decent in a three-way preflop scenario. Calling 15 to see a flop keeps your options open (two overs and backdoor draws) and has positive expected value with the current pot odds, while a fold would be too tight and going all-in is too risky.
We’re in the BB getting excellent pot odds versus a button min-raise and SB call. T5o is too weak to squeeze and too good to fold for 10 into 50; call and see a flop with low SPR.

Flop 8d 8h Qc gives you a Queen pair with Ace kicker (Ad Qh). With two opponents to act, this is a value/protection bet to deny backdoor outs and charge draws (like A-x or 8x). A 30-chip bet keeps you in a comfortable stack position (you'd have ~20 left if called) while offering fold equity and room to back up on later streets. If called or raised, you can re-evaluate turn.

We have T5o with no pair or strong draws on Q-8-8, multiway. Charlie’s lead commits his short stack (20 behind), indicating strength; poor equity and bad float spot with button behind. Preserve chip lead and fold.

I have only Ace-high on a Q-8-8 flop with no meaningful draws. Charlie’s bet and prior action indicate strength and he’s effectively pot-committed as a short stack. Preserve chips and wait for a better spot.
